So, with the pigeons, they had no information prior to being put in the box. So I feel the humans should have had no information. The humans being made believe they were on a game show and that they could "keep all they money they got" literally made them believe after getting money that they in turn had to do something to get the money. If they went in there with no information, no instructions, no idea of the premise what so ever, I think the outcome may have been different, or at the very least would have taken a lot longer to achieve or replicate. And Michael, You know as well as I do, that in order for the results of the test to be the most accurate, the test must be performed as EXACTLY the same as the previous test you are studying.  Anything else skews the results and dare i say makes them wrong. If a person believes they are going to win money while they are in a room for 10 minutes, as soon as the money gets spit out they are going to correlate something they did to the reason the money came out. Not only that, they are going to "try" to get as much money as possible cause that is the whole purpose they were even there in the first place.  It's just basic human nature. This leans heavily into "confirmation bias". Game shows are not random and everybody knows that. And the object of a game show for the person who is playing is to win as much money as they can in the allotted time. I also assume if it was 30 minutes or 60 minutes, they would have realized the pattern was in the amount of time between dollars not in anything they did. It's basic cause and effect. And that's where anybody with no information about a situation would start, once things start happening. "did I cause this" "let me try to replicate what i did, to see if I can replicate what the money did". These are the fundamental steps in solving any problem or coming up with an answer to a question you never knew existed.

So, if pigeons have been shown to exhibit this "superstitious behavior", that would indicate it's an evolutionary thing that must give more advantages than it has downsides. This evolutionary developed phenomenon of course it what allows any creatures to be trained.
Also worth noting is that it would require the pigeon to consciously remember what they were doing prior to the food being dispensed in order to recreate those actions it THINKS might result in a reward. I am curious as to how many alternate things the pigeons tried out or if they quickly become locked into only one with no further attempts to alter the behavior to try new "theories" about what triggers the food dispenser when the previous attempts fail.

I would also argue that this does not indicate that superstitions are weird or stupid and that superstitious behavior is nothing more than us trying to figure out an "unknown mechanism". I would also argue that superstitious behavior in animals actually indicates a high level of intelligence and mental faculties, like observation, memory, and most importantly, the realization that there we are all surrounded by "unknown mechanisms" that we may be able to control or at least influence.

This also proves that animals exhibiting "superstitious behavior" is actually evidence that they have a grasp of "cause and effect" as well as that they can alter an effect if they can alter the cause of an effect. To me, that indicates a high level of intelligence not normally associated with animals.

It was almost like they had set up the scenario themselves and were trying to connect the dots and understand what was expected in real time. Those that accepted the implied paradigm, the religious/scientific narrative as a starting point, showed a tendency to carry that implied narrative forward creatively. They allowed for the subjectivity in what was implied, and free associated ala Rorschach. Reality exists in the balance between the two.

It's important to distinguish between superstitious beliefs and split-test experimentation. Both look the same at the beginning but split-testing is the correct analytical/scientific approach.

Essentially, when going into the victory vault, without any additional information, yes you would press the button and if money comes out and the delay of it coming out if possible. Then you would press it again to see if the delay is the same. Then you would jump or do whatever action.

To continue doing it if it works isn't necessarily superstituous if the correlation is roughly correct - every time you press a button, the money comes out roughly 20-25 seconds later. It just simply means you haven't had enough time to find the true correlation, but it worked 80% of the time.

This is the same in science. You do experiments to find out the truth in the world. If it's accurate with a 95% confidence level, it's pretty much believed.

Similar to how we now believe particles behave as both waves and particles.... was it superstitious to believe particles were not waves? Of course not... that was the best information we had at the time based on the data.

So while yes, some people are superstitious because the correlation isn't there... if the correlation IS there... I wouldn't be so fast to call something superstitious as the data supports the correlation.

When authority appears to want certain results and something's been built up to produce or induce certain reactions or behaviors, those who participate will do so depending on the prompting and props(parameters)used as well their susceptibility to being convinced by things beyond their standards of what they consider good evidence. Even if it doesn't meet the standards of actual good evidence.

Who remembers an art installation in the Seattle-Tacoma airport that consisted of a wall of lights and a panel of unlabeled buttons in a small lounge? The problem with the first experiment is that they're getting put into the box primed with the expectation of receiving money and that it's a game show.  People are preconditioned in our culture to expect that you have to have some kind of input in order to receive the reward, furthermore that game shows are a form of entertainment, that they involved puzzles.  I'd see more validity with the experiment if the individual put in the box had no cultural reference to game show television and no pre-loading of expectation from the "producer".  I also see similar problems in the "reverse exorcism", a pre-loading of expectations causing the subjects to perform for recognition, to be impressive.

Concerning the Skinner Box. I don't see what's so difficult to understand. What we're witnessing is an evolutionary function which explains one of many reasons that brains evolved and and effect that made bigger brains beneficial enough to drive bigger brain development.
1- those creatures that exhibited the "superstitious behavior" would in fact find ways of interacting with the environment that did reward them in some way for behaving in certain ways. Most times it would not but many times it would.

2- The larger the brain the more complex behaviors could be conceived of and tested against the environment to discover more complex ways of receiving life rewards whether it be in food gathering, predator survival mate selection or whatever.

3- we call it science and experimentation. The difference is science does it more methodically and with better documentation of results.

4- It is also the same mechanism that is the foundation for why conditioning or "training" worked to domesticate and train animals as well as humans.

I work in a casino and see strange superstitious behavior on a nightly basis. Most of the behaviors seem to have spread as a kind of common belief. I see tons of people doing things to the slot machines themselves such as smashing the play button as hard as possible, pressing the buttons in a certain order, and rubbing or touching certain areas of the screen.
There are also beliefs about our surveillance team monitoring every guest who's playing individually. Some say that we track their player cards and that having their card out of the machine gives them more payouts. Others think we track the amount of money they have in the machine and that only putting in smaller bills will show that they're not a "high roller" and thus cause us to think twice about taking so much money from them.
Of course it's all nonsense and the payouts are determined by a simple mathematic formula involving a few variables such as total money that has gone into the machine and total money that has been paid out. To "win" at a slot machine is more about being on a machine that was going to pay out regardless at the right time rather than any action you as an individual take. I've seen extreme cases that combine all of these superstitions where people will hit buttons rapidly and take their card in and out of the machine while touching the screen. At least it provides us workers with a bit of entertainment.

I'd like to point out something that I think might be a complication in the first experiment, Victory Vault. (Obviously, a channel as big as Vsauce doesn't have the time to dig for comments like these, but... I'll take my stab anyway.)

You told them that Victory Vault was a game show, yes? "Game" being the important word there. In most games, we as the players are the catalyst for several important events within the game. Particularly, when it comes to the end goal of a game, we have always been put in the position of needing to take the initiative. Not only this, but the mechanics of the game and the abilities it provides us are directly connected to achieving that very same goal. You could go so far as to say that whether or not you win the game is under your indirect control.

As a result, in your game show experiment- it's possible you were setting up for exactly the conditions you were expecting. In the context of a game, it would legitimately be less reasonable to assume you had no form of control. You have also been taught to trust the designers of the game, namely that they have given you some form of control. By this reasoning, it's only natural for people to begin searching for a way to exercise the control that they've been conditioned to believe they already have.

I was thinking about this episode, as I admittedly do often, and it occurred to me superstition is a perspective. Using the Skinnerbox for example, an individual coincidentally behaving uniquely, at the exact time necessary, would produce an outcome relative to their perspective. They would not be wrong, but rather merely ignorant.

Imagine that world and the difficulty convincing participants they're wrong. You're not imagining a world you don't already know because it's simply not possible. Your imagination is limited based on prior observations and the acquired knowledge. Superstitious beliefs in this context are constructs, and while I cannot see the precise connection here, I know for certain the Skinnbox doesn't accurately reflect what we think superstitious beliefs are. This needs to be examined from a different level or perspective, and perhaps one we're incapable of. Michael's expressed apprehension to the Skinnerbox test, indicates an intuitive suspicion of inherent flaws or inaccuracies. Maybe that's the superstitious result. This test, while not innately wrong, produced flaws in perspective and psychological methodology.

This may not be scientifically progressive and it may be detrimental. The hilarious paradox required in Science; You're required to remember that our best knowledge isn't absolute truth. That's fucking terrifying because the scientific inclination will inevitably produce studies, verifying the skinnerbox, within a test with a skinnerbox, within a test with a skinnerbox, et cetera... I'm saddened by this because I fear science is discovering what's possible to already be known, while not discovering the unknowable.

If there's one thing I know for sure, it's that humans don't backtrack easily. Adapt and move forward at any cost. This mentality is a problem and it's fucking lazy.

Addendum because of laziness: I guess my point is, if we want to move forward we should fix what we've messed up. This alone will create scientific progress where Science cannot. We should question the obstacles before there's a forceful paradigm shift, and there will be one.

There are some serious points of critique that perhaps could be raised on the methods used in this video.

- First, the first experiment is interesting indeed but the high amount of bias and the short amount of time that the participants were subject to cannot be considered as showing anything really. Actually, the experiment can prove the opposite in that the persons involved immediately looked for a cause (after they were told that they "had to do something" ie get money). A better experiment would have been if (like the pigeons) people could - without any bias - approach the money giving machine, for instance in the street. Noone would have thought of dancing there ahah.

- Second, the second experimetn was unethical inmho. First of all you didn't prove at all that the "faith" of the persons invovled affected the results, because of an underestimated improtant factor...they were hypnotised! The psychiatrist used Eirksonian Neurolinguistic programming - pehrpas the strongest form of hypnosis - to induce patients into that state and then you used that state to prove a point. Secondly, the black woman that felt that "something mystical" happened was the saddest case. If you hear what she says you'll understand that she lost her mother, so doing an experiment where (as is obvious to all in the comment section) you indirectly mock people's sensitiivities is unethical. Either the persons invovled were actors or (worse) you abused their sensitivities. I love VSauce but this time was a big flop. For me it's thumbs down this time unfortunately.

Damn, Michael, that's pretty sophisticated for a 5 subject YouTube study.  Your conclusion that the human mind is hard-wired to create spiritual/superstitious experience is excellent, but about 2º off-target.  What the human mind is designed to do is create ANSWERS to questions, mysteries, dilemmas.  They don't necessarily have to be metaphysical.  It all derives from the way that our species filled it's environmental niche in the Ice Age.  Our survival was not dependent on physical strength, long canine teeth, a thick fur coat, foot speed, hyper-acute vision etc.  No, it was our CREATIVITY that defined our niche.  It's important to understand that I don't mean "intelligence."  Intelligence and creativity are different things.  Cetaceans, crows, other primates, some cephalopods (the octopus), elephants and others are all intelligent in their own ways.  Our survival depended, instead, on our ability to take old information from the environment and with it, make new things, routines, ideas, more complex and abstract creations.  With creativity our ancestors (people just like us, by the way) could make work-arounds, tools to compensate for the lack of the aforementioned teeth, insulating coat, speed, strength, hyper-vision, whatever.  Building on our experience with the tools at our disposal to that point, we were able to evolve culture, which expands as the supply of novel creations does, exponentially.  A spiritual experience is just one of many subsets of creations which served a purpose.

About exorcists (which maybe it would have been fair to explain a little bit, but on the other hand, the church's exorcists were only briefly mentioned and in no way relevant to this episode):
They know that what they are doing is, well, bullshit, so to speak.
However, they still want to help their patients. In medieval times already, people where often thought to be possessed by demons when, by today's stnadrads and observations, they most likely had a mental illness causing their behaviour. Catholic exorcists are trained to recognize mental illnesses and get the affected people the help they need, from medical/psychological professionals.
However, with some people, the demon doesn't have to a mental illness, but can rather be a placebo effect, maybe caused by some circumstance. Now, the person believes they are possessed, leading to the correspoinding behaviour. In this case, the exorcists will often perform a Hollywood-like exorcism, with crucifix, holy water and all, not to actually get rid of a demon, but to lead to a healing placebo effect that beats the original one. It's similar to psychic surgery, only that the patient often really doesn't know it's fake.

25:18 "Everything we did in the room was a lie." They weren't lies. Too many people conflate the material with "truth." I was guilty of this of a long time. Rationally I don't think God is real. Materially I think it's pretty clear God isn't real. But the spiritual has a completely different epistemology than the material. It's a world of symbols and metaphor used to talk about the deep mysteries of what it means to be human and how we render the world meaningful. Just because the metaphor isn't literally, materially true, doesn't mean the metaphor is a lie. That's like calling a fable a lie. Of course the tortoise never beat the hare. That doesn't make Aesop a liar. By using existing, well-known symbols you were able to create a ritual that spoke to people on that metaphorical level. That's not a lie. It's just a different sort of truth.

This behavior reminds me of OCD--obsessive compulsive disorder. With my OCD, I have learned that the brain will send out red flags [fight or flight responses] simply because of reactivity towards them. People do counting tiles, excessive hand washing, rationalizing [defense of character] over unwanted thoughts, but in the end, none of this triggers the brain into a state of calm: instead, the mind sends more of the unpleasant emotions they have been trying to be free of, inadvertently caused by their 'superstitious' or ritualistic like reactions [which can become quite meditative and severe]; in psychology, this is known as a compulsive habit.
There are two primary motivational drives, which I have crudely divided into these hunked categories, out of convenience: urges [desires, impulses, cravings, hunger etc.] and compelling feelings [basically when looked at for under the surface reveal passive aggressive, controlling fixing behaviors, via various stimulus from perceived threats: the emotions following, fear, anger, guilt, hatred, shame, embarrassment, humiliation, loneliness, sadness, depression, anxiety, betrayal, jealousy, envy, grief, etc.]
Since we have evolved from the wild, our psycho-social abilities have become harassed by synthetic environments--a new kind of pain has arrived--from which mental stress arises; we are forced to learn how to be happy, healthy animals in a foreign world that we have not yet fully adapted to--much erratic human dissonance I think can be explained through this. We have to learn hard, now, because it's either a prosperous future with technology, post-apocalyptic strangulation [death wave] and or back to the wilderness entirely.

The first time you meet a new human being, you take as input how he looks. After he talks to you, you take as input what he/she said, and the way he/she said that thing. That gives you the first impression of everything new you meet.


When they got to the exorcism room, everybody explored the new unknown environment. Because they knew nothing about, brain took as definitive argument the look of the room,the look of things in it, the look of the people around, and created a belief, let's call it "y".


After that,the brain subject took as parameter "y" alongside what he/she heard from people in the room. The belief got updated, let's call it "y2".


After n steps, our starting "y" became "yn".


"yn" - Is the final verdict of the subject.

The problem with this experiment is that you tell them that the aim is to collect as much money as they can. The word "aim" implies that specific behaviors they engage in are going to result in the desired outcome (i.e. collecting the money). Skinner's pigeons did not go into the Skinner box with this mentality. If done on humans, this experiment should be done in a more naturalistic and unobtrusive fashion, where participants do not have an "aim" in mind.

I just thought of this. When it comes to disciplining children I think the insights  from the skinner box experiments are actually pretty amazing. The child being disciplined (a time out for example) would try to find ways out of the punishment or stop it early. As a parent, you have control over which behavior and thus belief the child can be reinforced with. If you want your child to be calm and not throw a tantrum and exercise patience, you’d have to be vigilant for that behavior and reward and reinforce that positively to reinforce that behavior and belief. I want to be clear that the people your show consult along with the professor you featured probably understand this way better than me, but I think there is quite a significant bias that you're adding in demonstration 1.  When Michael refers to the experiment as a game, he is implicitly telling the subjects that their actions will affect the outcome, and he is reinforcing that even more when he says that their goal is to collect as much money as possible.  In essence, this test opens with an authority figure, the producer of the show, telling them that the should be looking for ways to increase their winnings, biasing them against the idea that they can't affect their winnings.

The pigeons have no such preconceptions but develop superstitious behavior organically.
